recent_25_results.question: 3.6 When defining a recursive function, what are possible causes for infinite recursion?
recent_25_results.student_answer: 3.6 no base case, or the recursive calls do not converge to the base case

recent_25_results.question: 3.6 When defining a recursive function, what are possible causes for infinite recursion?
recent_25_results.student_answer: 3.6 No base case, or an incorrectly written recursion step that does not converge on the base case will lead to infinite recursion.

recent_25_results.question: 3.6 When defining a recursive function, what are possible causes for infinite recursion?
recent_25_results.student_answer: 3.6 If the recursion function never reaches or successfully defines the base case it will recurse forever. This happens many ways, such as the function doesn't progress towards the base case, or the function is coded poorly and doesn't even contain a base case.

recent_25_results.question: 3.6 When defining a recursive function, what are possible causes for infinite recursion?
recent_25_results.student_answer: 3.6 not creating a base case, or in the case where the base case will never be met.

recent_25_results.question: 3.6 When defining a recursive function, what are possible causes for infinite recursion?
recent_25_results.student_answer: 3.6 improper handling of cases such that not all possible values are able to be handled.

recent_25_results.question: 3.6 When defining a recursive function, what are possible causes for infinite recursion?
recent_25_results.student_answer: 3.6 There is no base case. The recursion step doesn't reduce the problem during each recursive call.

recent_25_results.question: 3.6 When defining a recursive function, what are possible causes for infinite recursion?
recent_25_results.student_answer: 3.6 no base case, as in a single return that does not include calling the function again. a static value to end at.

recent_25_results.question: 3.6 When defining a recursive function, what are possible causes for infinite recursion?
recent_25_results.student_answer: 3.6 Either omitting the base case, or writing the recursion step incorrectly so the it does not reach the base case can cause infinite recursion.

recent_25_results.question: 3.6 When defining a recursive function, what are possible causes for infinite recursion?
recent_25_results.student_answer: 3.6 omitting the base case or writing the recursive call so that it does not converge upon the base case.

recent_25_results.question: 3.6 When defining a recursive function, what are possible causes for infinite recursion?
recent_25_results.student_answer: 3.6 Either omitting the base case, or writing the recursion step incorrectly so that it does not converge on the base case

recent_25_results.question: 3.6 When defining a recursive function, what are possible causes for infinite recursion?
recent_25_results.student_answer: 3.6 Infinite recursion may occur if no base case is defined or if the call is not varied.

recent_25_results.question: 3.6 When defining a recursive function, what are possible causes for infinite recursion?
recent_25_results.student_answer: 3.6 Not having a base case, or building a recursion process that doesn't converge on the base case.

recent_25_results.question: 3.6 When defining a recursive function, what are possible causes for infinite recursion?
recent_25_results.student_answer: 3.6 Either omitting the base case, or writing the recursion step incorerectly

recent_25_results.question: 3.6 When defining a recursive function, what are possible causes for infinite recursion?
recent_25_results.student_answer: 3.6 no base case or if the programmar does not define the base case as the simplest case and it never gets reached

recent_25_results.question: 3.6 When defining a recursive function, what are possible causes for infinite recursion?
recent_25_results.student_answer: 3.6 No easily reached base case and no base case at all

recent_25_results.question: 3.6 When defining a recursive function, what are possible causes for infinite recursion?
recent_25_results.student_answer: 3.6 function is never allowed to reach the 'base case'

recent_25_results.question: 3.6 When defining a recursive function, what are possible causes for infinite recursion?
recent_25_results.student_answer: 3.6 it has no base case, or the base case is never met

recent_25_results.question: 3.6 When defining a recursive function, what are possible causes for infinite recursion?
recent_25_results.student_answer: 3.6 recursion refers to situations in which functions call themselves. These types of functions are known as recursive functions. That being said Infinite recursion occurs when the function is designed in such a way as to call it self forever without stopping possible causes

recent_25_results.question: 3.7 What are the similarities between iteration and recursion?
recent_25_results.student_answer: 3.7 Both involve a controlled repetition structures, and they both have a termination test. Also both of them can loop forever.

recent_25_results.question: 3.7 What are the similarities between iteration and recursion?
recent_25_results.student_answer: 3.7 As discussed earlier, recursion may be used to process iterative actions. Recursion is used for calculations where the answer can be described in a function that relates to itself.

recent_25_results.question: 3.7 What are the similarities between iteration and recursion?
recent_25_results.student_answer: 3.7 Both iteration and recursion are based on control statements and involve repetition. They can both also occur indefinitely.

recent_25_results.question: 3.7 What are the similarities between iteration and recursion?
recent_25_results.student_answer: 3.7 Both are based on a control statement - Iteration-repetition structure - Recursion-selection structure Both involve repetition -Iteration-explicitly uses repetition structure -Recursion-repeated function calls Both involve a termination test -Iteration-loop-termination test -Recursion-base case Both gradually approach termination -Iteration-modifies counter until loop-termination test fails -Recursion-produces progressively simpler versions of problem Both can occur indefinitely -Iteration-if loop-continuation condition never fails -Recursion-if recursion step does not simplify the problem

recent_25_results.question: 3.7 What are the similarities between iteration and recursion?
recent_25_results.student_answer: 3.7 Iteration and recursion have many similarities: both are based on a control statement, involve repetition, involve a termination test, gradually approach termination and can occur infinitely.

recent_25_results.question: 3.7 What are the similarities between iteration and recursion?
recent_25_results.student_answer: 3.7 Both rely on repetition, both have a base case, both can become an infinite loop. Anything recursive can also be solved with iteration.

recent_25_results.question: 3.7 What are the similarities between iteration and recursion?
recent_25_results.student_answer: 3.7 Both will repeat (loop) until a condition is met, and exit the loop. Both are capable of entering an infinite loop.
